Key Arguments: The government should not be the arbiter of truth, as defining truth is philosophically complex and practically impossible.
The bill violates human rights, specifically the implied freedom of speech and Article 19 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.
It undermines democracy by potentially censoring the free press and citizen journalism.
The legislation is ineffective and dangerous, as it could stifle scientific debate and innovation.
The bill could lead to negative consequences, such as decreased trust in government and media, and stymied innovation.
Exemptions for government and traditional media suggest targeted political application.
The presence of misinformation and disinformation is not the root cause of harm; rather, stifling free speech is.
Notable Quotes: This bill is Orweillian, in defining what is/isnâ€™t acceptable speech by Government fiat.
Censorship of anything but absolute mathematical truth guarantees getting it wrong.
The problems of mis/disinformation are not solved by centralising authority, but by increasing trust.
Exempting the Government and Traditional Media from this Bill is hypocritical.
